Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2009 10:48AM Connie07 wrote: Hi Selena, I've never been happy with the results of a lumpectomy. However, I'm 2 years out now and cancer free. There's a lot worse things than having to deal with a dent in a breast. No, it's not pretty, they didn't do it for pretty. It's never going to be the same, but it's there.  And if you read thru some of the other posts about surgeries and aftereffects, you'll see that we all feel violated and scarred for life. That a lot of women are just glad they still have a breast in that place. I"m really glad I still have one, it's smaller and it's funny looking when I lean over or lay on my side, but the only other one who really sees it is my husband and he tends to 'favor' that side, like a wounded pet, sort of. The emotional side is difficult, but again, if you'll spend a little time reading in this site -under the vast list of forums and even larger lists of topics under each one, you'll find that you are in an exclusive group of incredibly supportive and wise women who have been thru or are still or even yet again going through a WHOLE LOT of worse stuff. It will help you put things in perspective. And you'll find that you have choices you can make, or not, and no matter what you choose or how you heal from this, this family will support you. I promise. ~Connie
Posts.Title: Dimpling in breast after surgery SelenaRG Annabella58

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 12:01AM - edited Jun 12, 2011 12:04AM by Connie07 What a relief, to hear anything. Judie, you should consider detective work, thank you for contacting her sister and thanks to the sister that helped this community breathe a collective sigh of relief. Now, I think is a great time to offer spiritual support from each of us in our own way, say a prayer, light a candle, meditate on healing vibes, in Elizabeth's name. She needs the universal support and I know, for sure, that she deserves at least that. And, of course, CAKE as soon as possible. She made me laugh so many times, in the beginning of our friendship in here and she supported me when needed the most. THANK YOU, KK, FOR THE LAUGHS! Your compassion and humor are unique. I'm, very concerned but know that helping hands are ready and waiting to help you. I pray and wish for you to have the strength to survive this episode from hell and come back to us. . . . . . Theres chocolate fudge 7 layer CAKE with your name on it so you have to be the first one to dip a piece into the virtual dark chocolate fountain, in the Grand Ballroom and we won't start without you! With love, Connie

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 06:00PM Connie07 wrote: Hey Elizabeth, Happy Birthday!!  Now I know why I enjoy reading about you so much.... I'm an Aries too, April 4 is my birthday and I can hardly believe its on Easter Sunday this year, that has never happened before, at least not in my lifetime. Damn Medical Doctors for not working with you in a more appropriate manner. I'm pissed off at one of mine. Saw him on the 18th March and he ordered MRIs of both hips. Well, the order finally got to the hospital but its wrong, doesn't specify contrast or not. Doctors office is moving, literally, this weekend. Their old number is disconnected and their new number is not yet posted. I will try to go by their new location, in the hospital, tomorrow and try to find the nurse or the office person and get it straight. Seems like they make it a challenge just to schedule an MRI. Well, that was one rant for today, Happy Easter Happy Spring ~Connie

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2010 12:36PM Connie07 wrote: Hey!  The best part is you get to become one of us... and this is the most awesome place to be! Other women just don't know what they are missing. A Big WELCOME and just look how many are surviving these days! I was a holiday waiting patient. Had a punch biopsy on the BC side on Wed, the 23rd Dec. Didn't even see it coming. It sucked waiting til after Christmas, I didn't tell but a couple of people cause I didn't want to see 'that look' from any family much less extended family that you only see at Christmas anyway. but the result was B9 and I hope yours will be too. And I learned a new abbreviation NED = No Evidence of Disease. You know, we all have trials, its what keeps us going, rather the overcoming of trials gives women the courage and wisdom to help other women. Always has, always will. Men just don't get it. This is an intensly personal time in your life, albiet, unwanted. But you have reached out, and there will be many others who will come, befriending, supporting, encouraging and informing in the most wonderful of ways. Good Luck Wishing a big B9 for you. ~Connie
Posts.Title: waiting ...waiting...waiting artistang artistang

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 01:16PM Connie07 wrote: Oh, Good Heavens NO. You aren't doing much more than sedating yourself and relieving your pain. I thought maybe... me too. I'm on anti-inflamatory 2x a day, muscle relaxers 3x a day, and Hydrocodone 10 as many as 4 but usually about 2 a day and it helps me get through and keeps me from wigging out. It helps me deal with all kinds of stressors and I'm not getting it illegally. My PCP doesn't like that I take so much, but he understands, and I see a Pain Management Doc who was very cautious about my meds, and the only real side effect is that the next time I undergo surgery it could take more drugs to put and keep me zonked out for the duration. Just the fact that you are FEELING is good. If you start to feel bad and you pop one, it helps and makes you feel better. You can still drive, work, cook, deal. Know what I mean? So, no, you are not a druggy and I would challenge anyone who said you were. Connie
Posts.Title: Do you ever feel you will get addicted to pain meds? Reneepals barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 12:00PM Connie07 wrote: OMG.. After five years the side effects continue to haunt me. I do not know whete to turn. My BS is not who i want to see again, as well as my Rad.Onc. They lie and hide facts which really pisses me off. Im 95% sure ive developed BP in radiated side, all the symptoms have developed over a year to a point where l need help. Where do l go? Should l call the cancer center and ask for a referral to a le therapist? I just want an eval for le and bp. Dont want the bogus, costly visit where they say maybe, maybe not, try this or that and come back & pay more co-pays before we send you to the proper help? I dont think asking for an eval should be so hard to get. Im clean on mammos but have had discomfort on bc side ever since surgery. Saw ortho, said it was not rotator cuff. Pain management Doc has sent me to an addiction MD to get off pain meds. Seems like there isnt a real doc out there who gives half a damn. Im miserable.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 07:35PM Connie07 wrote: Thanks Cindy, there are two nearby centers. The one where its out of network for ins. And the one where my former BS and RO is, and most likely l'll have to go there, i called their rehab unit but they req a drs referral. im going to try to get that from my PC tomorrow. I didnt think about the rads center having post rad care, really think the doc would deny this is an SE of treatment. But l will call and ask. The front desk ladies were really nice. Has anyone experienced random bruising on the involved arm? I have. always small round bruises on the inside of treated arm. Not bigger than a quarter. Thats been going on since jan this year. Or itching on skin surface? Same spot has random itchy flares, several years now. Thx for concern and suggestions, love these boards for the real help. ~Connie

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 05:15PM Connie07 wrote: In today's world, there are lots of times when you cannot distinguish gender. the kids dress in so many different ways, with hair from all gone to matted up dread lengths. I think all of you that have had to deal with hair loss are AMAZINGLY STRONG WOMEN. I get called Sir all the time over the phone and through speakers.The first time I was a teen, living at home, answered the phone and some dumb man said, "Joe?", (dad's name.)  I answered NO, this is his son. They should teach phone/speaker workers to not assume gender. Although, if they are saying, yes maam, yes sir. well, you gotta give kudos for the manners. I'm more polite in those cases. It's almost fun to see the face when they see my old lady face knowing they called me Sir.
Posts.Title: Got called "Sir" this morning... Christine2000 americanpinay

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 01:59PM Connie07 wrote: Hi ladies, I saw my GYN on tuesday, he said that he did not think it's LE. unfortunately, after reading a lot, I disagree. Will go see the BS on Monday. I had a Lumbar epidural injection sched for tomorrow. BUT the GYN said that I have a vaginal infection (yet ANOTHER infection) and put me on 4 Flagyl all one dose and an AntiB cream. So, now I can't get the epidural cause they won't do it if you are on antiBiotics!!!!!!!!!!!   CURSES!  I've been trying to get a shot in my lumbar for TWO years. To relieve lower back pain and now it's taking over my upper legs. DRAT. it's like the universe doesn't want me to have an epidural because everytime I get close to actually doing it something like this infection happens or my insurance changed and the co-pay was $1,000.00. FOR ONE SHOT! Now, I can do it but now I can't cause of infection. Does anyone else have multiple infections?  That's what scares me about the swollen boob. If it is, and we all suspect that it is LE, it puts me AT RISK for infection?!?!   Holy crapola! Like I need another risk that I have no control over. Have to see BS. at least this time. Maybe I can get a new one this year. It's not that big a town but there are two different hospitals and 2 CA clinics. I know they all know each other and current BS is top of her group. But we graduated high school together and I wasn't fond of her then. HA But she's the only other one I can get in to see soon, so be it. I'm still scared to hear her say it's LE. Connie
Posts.Title: could this be LE? MicheleS Binney4

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2008 08:21AM Connie07 wrote: Amber, the same area on my boost was really touchy for a long time it seemed. I still get stabs - the doc all say, everyone is different. But that '6 weeks' thing is pretty typical. They told me it can take up to two years to heal completely, especially if you are fair skinned. And I've learned that the lifting weight limit is a good thing to try to stick to as well. If you had whole breast rads, you should ask them about arm extension exercises as doing that can help the muscle underneath. If you don't do those, that muscle can get real tight and be sore for a long time. Good Luck, you're DONE. ~Connie
Posts.Title: Shooting pain in breast post radiation, anybody else? larousse Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 10:35AM Connie07 wrote: Cfdr, as every dr. You meet will say, "everybody's different". but they treat us much the same. I had and still do have pain below the breast on almost my side but closer to breast and the rib just under there. Kinda like a sharp muscle cramp that l cant hold but can't work out. I have to lie down and take deep breaths. Fortunately, they are fewer now. My LANAtrained LE therapist said, "it starts in the back, LE does..". Damn, I thought that was an itchy spot for at least a year. (I just reread that & it makes her sound like Yoda, it does.) Also, everything Ive read says its not cureable and never goes away, so if they treated you for it early, why didnt they keep on? Logic overrides protocol. If it were me, l would go back to PT and get an evaluation. Hopefully compared to the original measurements. Please, GO. And let us know. Connie

Posts.Title: WISHES (WHAT DO YOU WISH FOR) lizzie5308 lizzie5308

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 08:06PM Connie07 wrote: Thanks for asking. I have a couple of inches of scar tissue that has been painful every day since surgery. A recent mammo showed a lot more scarring than I expected, but nobody mentioned doing an MRI? Why not? If the radiologist can't see through the scar tissue and the whole purpose of a mammogram is to see through the breast then they should automatically recommend an MRI. Shouldn't they? For Christ's sake, isn't follow up supposed to follow up. this is so frustrating. No Doctor is any longer responsible for our whole-ness. I know I had read that a long time ago and asked for MRI and my BS, former BS, looked at me like I was crazy. Turns out, we think SHE is crazy. sort of anyway. She gave me no options and turns out there should have been options in 2007. She didn't suggest any dietary revisions. She didn't mention side effects, specifically scar tissue and LE. Last year a cyst appeared. She aspirated it and the whole area flared red and warm. It's STILL red there. She knew it was a cyst and that the fluid was b9 but weeks later did a punch biopsy anyway (because it was red) and suggested I may have a "little" LE. but she did nothing about it. Now I find that early detection is key to controlling LE and that it is a non curable, lifelong side effect. I'm seeing a new BS on Tuesday and will ask for LE eval. And now, maybe an MRI instead of a mammo that shows blotchy white spaces. I'm going on 4 years out and thought all this breast concern was behind me. Sadly, that's not the case. i wonder if it ever will. ~Connie
Posts.Title: Is scar tissue painful? Jaydra NaskarStar3

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 08:49AM Connie07 wrote: Oh yes. My burns and broken down skin were a problem for WEEKS. every time I moved it rubbed and hurt. I used ordinary Corn Starch like a powder, it really helped keep the worst areas really dry, and it helps the skin slide rather than rub. There was about three weeks where I couldn't wear a bra at all. Used it under the breast which was the worst, and under my arm which was pretty badly burned as well. Stayed in, mostly, with arm propped up. Camisoles are really nice.  But do NOT neglect your arm extension exercises, try and keep full range of movement. Good Luck with that, it will pass. ~Connie
